ygData.subject: Re: [eqbards] Charming in the outdoors (And fast mobs)
ygData.msgSnippet: Sounds like you re charming one, sicking it on your target then never re-targetting your pet.  IE:  Your charm breaks and then you re-charm the OTHER giant.
ygData.messageBody:
Sounds like you're charming one, sicking it on your target then never
re-targetting your pet. IE: Your charm breaks and then you re-charm the
OTHER giant. Your former pet is now VERY ticked off and will attack you
instead of the other giant.

If, instead, you do the following:

1) Charm target
2) Target enemy
3) /pet kill
4) Target Pet
5) do whatever for awhile
6) Recharm pet

The other giant should stop and fight your pet every time you re-charm.
----- Original Message -----
From: "Ioshua" <Ioshua@...>
To: <eqbards@egroups.com>
Sent: Friday, June 02, 2000 5:01 PM
Subject: Re: [eqbards] Charming in the outdoors (And fast mobs)


> Charming Cycs and Griffs? How do you get around the problem where the
> target is faster than your charm's melee and you have to take a hit
> before your charm can start the combat? It's the only reason why I'm
> not soloing the giant camp in Frontier Mtns right now. I can get one
> charmed and sic it on a second but when the charm breaks and I have to
> recharm my thrall the other giant gets far enough away that I have to
> take a hit (ouch) to keep it in place long enough for my pet to hit it.
> Am I doing something wrong or should I start mixing in chains on the
> target or what? Aanndd.. at best (w/o cha bracers and lambent) my
> charisma tops out at 133, that's with 2x cha rings, 1 lambent bracer, 1
> lambent gauntlet, +9cha neck and +13 from my MoD (yea yea, i didn't
> allocate any cha at start...)
>
>
> --- "Kevin L. Crawford" <Lyrnia@...> wrote:
> > I was able to charm them at level 30 but it's safer to do it at 32,
> > they resist a LOT at level 30 and 31. 32 it gets a lot better. I
> > stuck to Clopses and griffies and such till level 32.
> >
> > Lyrnia
>
